- $s$ зайг мөргөлдөхгүйгээр туулах хийн молекулуудын харьцангуй тоо: $$N / N_{0}=\mathrm{e}^{-s / \lambda} $$ Энд $\lambda$ нь дундаж чөлөөт зам юм.
- Хийн молекулын дундаж чөлөөт зам: $$\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi d^{2} n}, $$ Энд $d$ нь молекулын үр дүнтэй диаметр, $n$ нь нэгж эзэлхүүн дэх молекулуудын тоо юм.
- Хийн тархалтын коэффициент $D$ , зуурамтгай чанар $\eta$ , дулаан дамжуулах чадвар $\varkappa$ : $$D=\frac{1}{3}\langle v\rangle \lambda, \quad \eta=\frac{1}{3}\langle v\rangle \lambda \rho, \quad x=\frac{1}{3}\langle v\rangle \lambda \rho c_{V}, $$ Энд $\rho$ нь хийн нягт, $c_{V}$ нь тогтмол эзэлхүүн дэх дулааны хувийн багтаамж юм.
- Маш ховордсон хийн дэх ялтсуудын бие биентэйгээ параллель хөдөлгөөний үед нэгж талбайд үйлчлэх үрэлтийн хүч: $$F=\frac{1}{6}\langle v\rangle \rho\left|u_{1}-u_{2}\right| . $$ Энд $u_{1}$ ба $u_{2}$ нь ялтсуудын хурд юм.
- Маш ховордсон хийгээр хоёр хананы хооронд дамжих дулааны урсгалын нягт: $$q=\frac{1}{6}\langle v\rangle \rho c_{V}\left|T_{1}-T_{2}\right|, $$ Энд $T_{1}$ ба $T_{2}$ нь хананы температур юм.

statement.value:
As a result of some process the pressure of an ideal gas нэмэгдэнэ $n$-fold. How many дахин have the mean free path $\lambda$ and the number of collisions of each molecule per unit time $\nu$ changed and how, if the process is
(a) isochoric; (b) isothermal?

answer.value: (А) $\lambda=$ тогтмол, $v$ нэмэгдэнэ $\sqrt{n}$ дахин; (b) $\lambda$ буурна $n$ дахин, $v$ нэмэгдэнэ $n$ дахин.

statement.value:
An ideal gas consisting of rigid diatomic molecules goes through an adiabatic process. How do the mean free path $\lambda$ and the number of collisions of each molecule per second $v$ depend in this process on
(a) the volume $В$; (b) the pressure $p$; (c) the temperature $T$?

answer.value: (А) $\lambda \propto В, v \propto В^{-6 / 5}$; (b) $\lambda \propto p^{-5 / 7}, v \propto p^{6 / 7}$; (c) $\lambda \propto \propto T^{-5 / 2}, v \propto T^{3}$.

statement.value:
An ideal gas goes through a polytropic process with exponent $n$. Find the mean free path $\lambda$ and the number of collisions of each molecule per second $v$ as a function of
(a) the volume $В$; (b) the pressure $p$; (c) the temperature $T$.

answer.value: (А) $\lambda \propto В, \quad v \propto В^{-(n+1) / 2}$; (b) $\lambda \propto p^{-1 / n}, v \propto p^{(n+1) / 2 n}$; (c) $\lambda \propto T^{1 /(1-n)}, v \propto T^{(n+1) / 2(n-1)}$.

statement.value: Determine the molar heat capacity of a polytropic process through which an ideal gas consisting of rigid diatomic molecules goes and in which the number of collisions between the molecules remains тогтмолant }

An ideal gas of молийн масс $M$ is enclosed in a vessel of volume $В$ whose thin walls are kept at a тогтмолant temperature $T$. At a moment $t=0$ a small hole of area $S$ is opened, and the gas starts escaping into vacuum. Find the gas concentration $n$ as a function of time $t$ if at the initial moment $n(0)=n_{0}$.

answer.value: $N=n_{0} \mathrm{e}^{-t / \tau}$, энд $\tau=4 В / S\langle v\rangle,\langle v\rangle=\sqrt{8 R T / \pi M}$.

statement.value: А vessel filled with gas is divided into two equal parts 1 and 2 by a thin heat-insulating partition with two holes. One hole has a small diameter, and the other has a very large diameter (in comparison with the mean free path of molecules). In part 2 the gas is kept at a temperature $\eta$ дахин higher than that of part 1. How will the концентраци molecules in part 2 change and how many дахин after the large hole is closed?

As a result of a certain process the viscosity coefficient of an ideal gas нэмэгдэнэ $\alpha=2.0$ дахин and its diffusion coefficient $\beta=4.0$ дахин. How does the gas pressure change and how many дахин?

answer.value: (А) $D$ нэмэгдэнэ $n$ дахин, $\eta=$ тогтмол; (b) $D$ нэмэгдэнэ $n^{3 / 2}$ дахин, $\eta$ нэмэгдэнэ $\sqrt{n}$ дахин.

statement.value: An ideal gas consists of rigid diatomic molecules. How will a diffusion coefficient $D$ and viscosity coefficient $\eta$ change and how many дахин if the gas volume is decreased adiabatically $n=10$ дахин?

An ideal gas goes through a polytropic process. Find the polytropic exponent $n$ if in this process the coefficient
(a) of diffusion; (b) of viscosity; (c) of heat conductivity remains тогтмолant.
Knowing the viscosity coefficient of helium стандарт нөхцөлд, calculate the effective diameter of the helium atom.
The heat conductivity of helium is 8.7 дахин that of argon (стандарт нөхцөлд). Find the ratio of effective diameters of argon and helium atoms.

Стандарт нөхцөлд helium fills up the space between two long coaxial cylinders. The mean radius of the cylinders is equal to $R$, the gap between them is equal to $\Delta R$, with $\Delta R \ll R$. The outer cylinder rotates with a fairly low angular velocity $\omega$ about the тайван inner cylinder. Find the moment of friction forces acting on a unit length of the inner cylinder. Down to what magnitude should the helium pressure be lowered (keeping the temperature тогтмолant) to decrease the sought moment of friction forces $n=10$ дахин if $\Delta R=6 \mathrm{~мм}$?

answer.value: $N_{1} \approx 2 \pi \eta \omega R^{3} / \Delta R; p=\sqrt{2} k T / \pi d^{2} n \Delta R=0.7 \mathrm{~Па}$.

statement.value: А gas fills up the space between two long coaxial cylinders of radii $R_{1}$ and $R_{2}$, with $R_{1}<R_{2}$. The outer cylinder rotates with a fairly low angular velocity $\omega$ about the тайван inner cylinder. The moment of friction forces acting on a unit length of the inner cylinder is equal to $N_{1}$. Find the viscosity coefficient $\eta$ of the gas taking into account that the friction force acting on a unit area of the cylindrical surface of radius $r$ is determined by the formula $\sigma= =\eta r(\partial \omega / \partial r)$.

Two identical parallel discs have a common axis and are located at a distance $ц$ from each other. The radius of each disc is equal to $a$, with $a \gg ц$. One disc is rotated with a low angular velocity $\omega$ relative to the other, тайван, disc. Find the moment of friction forces acting on the тайван disc if the viscosity coefficient of the gas between the discs is equal to $\eta$.
Solve the foregoing problem, assuming that the discs are located in an ultra-rarefied gas of молийн масс $M$, температурт $T$ and under pressure $p$.

Making use of Poiseuille's equation (1.7d), find the mass $\mu$ of gas flowing per unit time through the pipe of length $л$ and radius $a$ if тогтмолant pressures $p_{1}$ and $p_{2}$ are maintained at its ends.

One end of a rod, enclosed in a thermally insulating sheath, is kept at a temperature $T_{1}$ while the other, at $T_{2}$. The rod is composed of two sections whose lengths are $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$ and heat conductivity coefficients $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$. Find the temperature of the interface.

Two rods whose lengths are $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$ and heat conductivity coefficients $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ are placed end to end. Find the he at conductivity coefficient of a uniform rod of length $l_{1}+l_{2}$ whose conductivity is the same as that of the system of these two rods. The lateral surfaces of the rods are assumed to be thermally insulated.

А rod of length $л$ with thermally insulated lateral surface consists of material whose heat conductivity coefficient varies with temperature as $x=\alpha / T$, энд $\alpha$ нь тогтмол. The ends of the rod are kept температуртs $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$. Find the function $T(x)$, энд $x$ is the distance from the end whose temperature is $T_{1}$, and the heat flow density.

Two chunks of metal with heat capacities $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ are interconnected by a rod of length $л$ and cross-sectional area $S$ and fairly low heat conductivity $x$. The whole system is thermally insulated from the environment. At a moment $t=0$ the temperature difference between the two chunks of metal equals $(\Delta T)_{0}$. Assuming the heat capacity of the rod to be negligible, find the temperature difference between the chunks as a function of time.

answer.value: $\Delta T=(\Delta T)_{0} \mathrm{e}^{-\alpha t}$, энд $\alpha=\left(1 / C_{1}+1 / C_{2}\right) S x / л$.

statement.value: Find the temperature distribution in a substance placed between two parallel plates kept температуртs $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$. The plate separation is equal to $л$, the heat conductivity coefficient of the substance $\varkappa \бар{\propto} \sqrt{T}$.

answer.value: $T=T_{1}\left\{1+(x / л)\left[\left(T_{2} / T_{1}\right)^{3 / 2}-1\right]\right\}^{2 / 3}$, энд $x$ is the distance from the plate maintained at the temperature $T_{1}$.

statement.value: The space between two large horizontal plates is filled with helium. The plate separation equals $л=50 \mathrm{~мм}$. The lower plate is kept at a temperature $T_{1}=290 \mathrm{~К}$, the upper, at $T_{2}= =330 \mathrm{~К}$. Find the heat flow density if the gas pressure is close to standard.

CONDUCTORS AND DIELECTRICS IN AN ELECTRIC FIELD}  \item Electric field strength near the surface of a conductor in vacuum:  \begin{equation*} E_{n}=\sigma / \varepsilon_{0}. \tag{3.2a} \end{equation*}  \item Flux of polarization $\mathbf{P}$ across a closed surface:  \begin{equation*} \oint \mathbf{P} d \mathbf{S}=-q^{\prime} \tag{3.2b} \end{equation*} энд $q^{\prime}$ is the algebraic sum of bound charges enclosed by this surface.  \item Vector D and Gauss's theorem for it:  \begin{equation*} \mathbf{D}=\varepsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P}, \quad \oint \mathbf{D} d \mathbf{S}=q \tag{3.2c} \end{equation*} энд $q$ is the algebraic sum of extraneous charges inside a closed surface.  \item Relations at the boundary between two dielectrics:  \begin{equation*} P_{2 n}-P_{1 n}=-\sigma^{\prime}, \quad D_{2 n}-D_{1 n}=\sigma, \quad E_{2 \tau}=E_{1 \tau}, \tag{3.2d} \end{equation*} энд $\sigma^{\prime}$ and $\sigma$ are the surface densities of bound and extraneous charges, and the unit vector $\mathbf{n}$ of the normal is directed from medium 1 to medium 2.  \item In isotropic dielectrics:  \begin{equation*} \mathbf{P}=\varkappa \varepsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}, \quad \mathbf{D}=\varepsilon \varepsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}, \quad \varepsilon=1+\varkappa. \tag{3.2e} \end{equation*}  \item In the case of an isotropic uniform dielectric filling up all the space between the equipotential surfaces:  \begin{equation*} \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{E}_{0} / \varepsilon. \tag{3.2f} \end{equation*} 3.54. ENERGY OF AN ELECTRIC FIELD}  \item Capacitance of a parallel-plate capacitor:  \begin{equation*} C=\varepsilon \varepsilon_{0} S / d \tag{3.3a} \end{equation*}  \item Interaction energy of a system of point charges:  \begin{equation*} Вт=\frac{1}{2} \sum q_{i} \varphi_{i}. \tag{3.3b} \end{equation*}  \item Total electric energy of a system with continuous charge distribution:  \begin{equation*} Вт=\frac{1}{2} \int \varphi \rho d В \tag{3.3c} \end{equation*}  \item Total electric energy of two charged bodies 1 and 2:  \begin{equation*} Вт=W_{1}+W_{2}+W_{12}, \tag{3.3d} \end{equation*} энд $W_{1}$ and $W_{2}$ are the self-energies of the bodies, and $W_{12}$ is the interaction energy.  \item Energy of a charged capacitor:  \begin{equation*} Вт=\frac{q В}{2}=\frac{q^{2}}{2 C}=\frac{C В^{2}}{2} \tag{3.3e} \end{equation*}  \item Volume density of electric field energy:  \begin{equation*} w=\frac{\mathbf{E D}}{2}=\frac{\varepsilon \varepsilon_{0} E^{2}}{2} \tag{3.3f} \end{equation*} 3.101. MAXWELL'S EQUATIONS}  \item Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction:  \begin{equation*} \mathscr{E}_{i}=-\frac{d \Phi}{d t} \tag{3.6a} \end{equation*}  \item In the case of a solenoid and doughnut coil:  \begin{equation*} \Phi=N \Phi_{1}, \tag{3.6b} \end{equation*} энд $N$ is the number of turns, $\Phi_{1}$ is the magnetic flux through each turn.  \item Inductance of a solenoid:  \begin{equation*} L=\mu \mu_{0} n^{2} В. \tag{3.6c} \end{equation*}  \item Intrinsic energy of a current and interaction energy of two currents:  \begin{equation*} Вт=\frac{L I^{2}}{2}, \quad W_{12}=L_{12} I_{1} I_{2} \tag{3.6d} \end{equation*}  \item Volume density of magnetic field energy:  \begin{equation*} w=\frac{B^{2}}{2 \mu \mu_{0}}=\frac{\mathbf{B H}}{2}. \tag{3.6e} \end{equation*}  \item Displacement current density:  \begin{equation*} \mathbf{j}_{\text {dis }}=\frac{\partial \mathrm{B}}{\partial t}. \tag{3.6f} \end{equation*}  \item Maxwell's equations in differential form:  $$  \begin{array}{ll} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \дахин \mathbf{E}=-\frac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t}, & \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{B}=0,
\boldsymbol{\nabla} \дахин \mathbf{H}=\mathbf{j}+\frac{\partial \mathbf{D}}{\partial t}, & \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{D}=\rho, \tag{3.6g} \end{array}  $$ энд $\boldsymbol{\nabla} \дахин \equiv$ rot (the rotor) and $\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \equiv \operatorname{div}$ (the divergence).  \item Field transformation formulas for transition from a reference frame $К$ to a reference frame $К^{\prime}$ moving with the velocity $\mathrm{v}_{0}$ relative to it.  In the case $v_{0} \ll{ }_{\mathbf{E}^{\prime}}$ \begin{equation*} \mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\mathbf{E}+\left[\mathbf{v}_{0} \mathbf{B}\right], \quad \mathbf{B}^{\prime}=\mathbf{B}-\left[\mathbf{v}_{0} \mathbf{E}\right] / c^{2} \tag{3.6h} \end{equation*} In the general case $$  \begin{array}{ll} \mathbf{E}_{\|}^{\prime}=\mathbf{E}_{\|}, & \mathbf{B}_{\|}^{\prime}=\mathbf{B}_{\|},  \tag{3.6i}
\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathbf{E}_{\perp}+\left[\mathbf{v}_{0} \mathbf{B}\right]}{\sqrt{1-\left(v_{0} / c\right)^{2}}}, & B_{\perp}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathbf{B}_{\perp}-\left[\mathbf{v}_{0} \mathbf{E}\right] / c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-\left(v_{0} / c\right)^{2}}}, \end{array}  $$ энд the symbols $\|$ and $\perp$ denote the field components, respectively parallel and perpendicular to the vector $v_{0}$.

\item Luminous intensity $I$ and illuminance $E$ :  \begin{equation*} I=\frac{d \Phi}{d \Omega}, \quad E=\frac{d \Phi_{i n c}}{d S}. \tag{5.1a} \end{equation*}  \item Illuminance produced by a point isotropic source:  \begin{equation*} E=\frac{I \cos \alpha}{r^{2}}, \tag{5.1b} \end{equation*} энд $\alpha$ is the angle between the normal to the surface and the direction to the source.  \item Luminosity $M$ and luminance $L$ :  \begin{equation*} M=\frac{d \Phi_{e м i t}}{d S}, \quad L=\frac{d \Phi}{d \Omega \Delta S \cos \theta}. \tag{5.1c} \end{equation*}  \item For a Lambert source $L=$ тогтмол and luminosity  \begin{equation*} M=\pi L. \tag{5.1d} \end{equation*}  \item Relation between refractive angle $\theta$ of a prism and least deviation angle $\alpha$ :  \begin{equation*} \sin \frac{\alpha+\theta}{2}=n \sin \frac{\theta}{2}, \tag{5.1e} \end{equation*} энд $n$ is the refractive index of the prism.  \item Equation of spherical mirror:  \begin{equation*} \frac{1}{s^{\prime}}+\frac{1}{s}=\frac{2}{R}, \tag{5.1f} \end{equation*} энд $R$ is the curvature radius of the mirror.  \item Equations for aligned optical system (Зур. 5.2):  \begin{equation*} \frac{n^{\prime}}{s^{\prime}}-\frac{n}{s}=\Phi, \frac{f^{\prime}}{s^{\prime}}+\frac{f}{s}=1, \quad x x^{\prime}=f f^{\prime}. \tag{5.1g} \end{equation*}

\item Relations between focal lengths and optical power:  \begin{equation*} f^{\prime}=\frac{n^{\prime}}{\Phi}, \quad f=-\frac{n}{\Phi}, \quad \frac{f^{\prime}}{f}=-\frac{n^{\prime}}{n}. \tag{5.1h} \end{equation*}  \item Optical power of a spherical refractive surface:  \begin{equation*} \Phi=\frac{n^{\prime}-n}{R}. \tag{5.1i} \end{equation*}  \item Optical power of a thin lens in a medium with refractive index $n_{0}$ :  \begin{equation*} \Phi=\left(n-n_{0}\right)\left(\frac{1}{R_{1}}-\frac{1}{R_{2}}\right), \tag{5.1j} \end{equation*} энд $n$ is the refractive index of the lens.  \item Optical power of a thick lens:  \begin{equation*} \Phi=\Phi_{1}+\Phi_{2}-\frac{d}{n} \Phi_{1} \Phi_{2}, \tag{5.1k} \end{equation*} энд $d$ is the thickness of the lens. This equation is also valid for a system of two thin lenses separated by a medium with refractive index $n$.  \item Principal planes $H$ and $H^{\prime}$ are removed from the crest points $O$ and $O^{\prime}$ of surfaces of a thick lens (Зур. 5.3) by the following distances:  \begin{equation*} X=\frac{d}{n} \frac{\Phi_{2}}{\Phi}, X^{\prime}=-\frac{d}{n} \frac{\Phi_{1}}{\Phi}. \tag{5.11} \end{equation*}

SCHRÖDINGER EQUATION}  \item The de Broglie wavelength of a particle with momentum $p$ :  \begin{equation*} \lambda=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{p}. \tag{6.2a} \end{equation*}  \item Uncertainty principle:  \begin{equation*} \Delta x \cdot \Delta p_{x} \geqslant \hbar \tag{6.2b} \end{equation*}  \item Schrödinger time-dependent and time-independent equations:  \begin{gather*} i \hbar \frac{\partial \Psi}{\partial t}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 м} \nabla^{2} \Psi+U \Psi,
